mainmatter.p: I am an undergraduate Math-CS major at Reed College. My pronouns are she/they.

frontmatter.title: Categorical phase semantics for linear logic

mainmatter.p: Linear logic is a logic of limited resources, useful in practice for writing safe programs. Girard's phase semantics, which may be instantiated with any (classical) monoid, are a canonical model of this logic. We give a categorical generalization of phase semantics to monoid objects in certain categories, filling an existing hole in the categorical semantics of linear logic. Along the way, we introduce and motivate the project of categorical semantics, assuming no knowledge of category theory or logic. This talk presents research with Steve Zdancewic at the UPenn PLClub group, supported by the REPL NSF REU site.
The following are all algebraic structures:
A magma is a set together with a binary operation.
A semigroup is a magma whose operation is associative.
A classical monoid is a semigroup with an identity.
A group is a classical monoid (G, \cdot , e) such that each element g \in G has a two-sided inverse g^{-1} \in G, i.e. such that g \cdot g^{-1} = g^{-1} \cdot g = e.
A group is abelian if its operation is commutative.
A ring is a set R which is both an abelian group (R, +) and a monoid (R, \times ), such that multiplication distributes over addition, i.e. r \times (s + q) = r \times s + r \times q.
A field is a ring which is also an abelian group under multiplication.
A module over a ring R, or just an R-module, is an abelian group (M, +) together with an action R \curvearrowright M which preserves the following structure:

ul.li: identities: 1_R \cdot x = x, 0_R \cdot x = 0_M;
distributivity: r \cdot (x+y) = r \cdot x + r \cdot y, (r+s) \cdot x = r \cdot x + s \cdot x;
multipication: r \cdot (s \cdot x) = (rs) \cdot x.

mainmatter.p: A vector space over a field F, or just an F-vector space, is a module over F.

An algebra over a ring R, or just an R-algebra, is an R-module which is also itself a ring, such that the action R \curvearrowright A commutes with the multiplication of A, as in r \cdot (ab) = (r \cdot a)b = a(r \cdot b).
A Lie algebra is a vector space \mathfrak{g} together with a binary operation [-, -], its Lie bracket, satisfying:

ul.li: skew-symmetry: [x, y] = -[y, x];
bilinearity: [x+cy, z] = [x, z] + c[y, z];
the Jacobi identity: [x, [y, z]] + [z, [x, y]] + [y, [x, z]] = 0.

mainmatter.p: A homomorphism of algebraic structures is a function which preserves (commutes with) all of the structure (operations, actions, and relations).
The characteristic of a ring R, \mathrm{char} R, is:

ul.li: the order of its underlying additive group, if finite;
0, otherwise.

mainmatter.p: Equivalently, let \varphi be the unique ring homomorphism \mathbb{Z} \rightarrow R. Then \mathrm{char} R is the natural number such that \mathrm{ker} \varphi = ( \mathrm{char} R) \mathbb{Z}.
A homomorphism of algebraic structures is a function which preserves (commutes with) all of the structure (operations, actions, and relations).
A poset has the least upper bound property if and only if it has the (dually defined) greatest lower bound property.
Let (X, \leq ) have the lub property; we show the glb property, and conclude by duality. Let Y \subseteq X be nonempty and bounded below. Let y \in Y.

Let L be the set of lower bounds of Y; L is nonempty since Y is bounded below. By definition of lower bound, l \leq y for all l \in L. Now L is bounded above by y, and hence has a supremum \bigvee L by the lub property. By definition of the supremum and construction of L, we have that \bigvee L \geq l for any lower bound l of Y; hence \bigvee L = \bigwedge Y, completing the proof.
An ordered field is a field (F, +, \cdot ) with a total order \leq, compatible

ul.li: additively: y < z implies x + y < x + z;
multiplicatively: 0 < x and 0 < y implies 0 < xy.

frontmatter.title: Ordered fields contain \mathbb{Q} as a subfield

mainmatter.p: Any ordered field contains a subfield isomorphic to \mathbb{Q}.
By elementary properties of ordered fields, any ordered field has characteristic 0, and hence contains a copy of \mathbb{Z}. Closing under multiplicative inverses gives a copy of \mathbb{Q}.
A preorder is a reflexive and transitive relation.

frontmatter.title: Proof of lub property iff glb property

mainmatter.p: Let (X, \leq ) have the lub property; we show the glb property, and conclude by duality. Let Y \subseteq X be nonempty and bounded below. Let y \in Y.

Let L be the set of lower bounds of Y; L is nonempty since Y is bounded below. By definition of lower bound, l \leq y for all l \in L. Now L is bounded above by y, and hence has a supremum \bigvee L by the lub property. By definition of the supremum and construction of L, we have that \bigvee L \geq l for any lower bound l of Y; hence \bigvee L = \bigwedge Y, completing the proof.

frontmatter.title: Proof of ordered fields contain \mathbb{Q} as a subfield

mainmatter.p: By elementary properties of ordered fields, any ordered field has characteristic 0, and hence contains a copy of \mathbb{Z}. Closing under multiplicative inverses gives a copy of \mathbb{Q}.

frontmatter.title: Proof of uniqueness of ordered fields with the lub property

mainmatter.p: Let (F, +, \cdot , \leq ) and (G, +, \cdot , \leq ) be ordered fields satisfying the lub property. It suffices to construct an ordered field isomorphism F \xrightarrow{\varphi} G.
Let \mathbb{Q} \xrightarrow{f} F and \mathbb{Q} \xrightarrow{g} G be injective with images the isomorphic copies of \mathbb{Q} in F and G.
TODO.
A partial order is total if any two elements are comparable, i.e., either x \leq y or y \leq x for every x and y in the set.

frontmatter.title: Uniqueness of ordered fields with the lub property

mainmatter.p: Any two ordered fields satisfying the least upper bound property are isomorphic as ordered fields.
Let (F, +, \cdot , \leq ) and (G, +, \cdot , \leq ) be ordered fields satisfying the lub property. It suffices to construct an ordered field isomorphism F \xrightarrow{\varphi} G.
Let \mathbb{Q} \xrightarrow{f} F and \mathbb{Q} \xrightarrow{g} G be injective with images the isomorphic copies of \mathbb{Q} in F and G.
TODO.
A Lie algebra is a vector space \mathfrak{g} together with a binary operation [-, -], its Lie bracket, satisfying:

ul.li: skew-symmetry: [x, y] = -[y, x];
bilinearity: [x+cy, z] = [x, z] + c[y, z];
the Jacobi identity: [x, [y, z]] + [z, [x, y]] + [y, [x, z]] = 0.

mainmatter.p: An action of a set Y on a set X, Y \curvearrowright X, is a function Y \times X \rightarrow X.
Often, we consider actions of a structured set, in which case we ask that the action preserve additional structure.

An algebra over a ring R, or just an R-algebra, is an R-module which is also itself a ring, such that the action R \curvearrowright A commutes with the multiplication of A, as in r \cdot (ab) = (r \cdot a)b = a(r \cdot b).
The following are all algebraic structures:
A magma is a set together with a binary operation.
A semigroup is a magma whose operation is associative.
A classical monoid is a semigroup with an identity.
A group is a classical monoid (G, \cdot , e) such that each element g \in G has a two-sided inverse g^{-1} \in G, i.e. such that g \cdot g^{-1} = g^{-1} \cdot g = e.
A group is abelian if its operation is commutative.
A ring is a set R which is both an abelian group (R, +) and a monoid (R, \times ), such that multiplication distributes over addition, i.e. r \times (s + q) = r \times s + r \times q.
A field is a ring which is also an abelian group under multiplication.
A module over a ring R, or just an R-module, is an abelian group (M, +) together with an action R \curvearrowright M which preserves the following structure:

ul.li: identities: 1_R \cdot x = x, 0_R \cdot x = 0_M;
distributivity: r \cdot (x+y) = r \cdot x + r \cdot y, (r+s) \cdot x = r \cdot x + s \cdot x;
multipication: r \cdot (s \cdot x) = (rs) \cdot x.

mainmatter.p: A vector space over a field F, or just an F-vector space, is a module over F.

An algebra over a ring R, or just an R-algebra, is an R-module which is also itself a ring, such that the action R \curvearrowright A commutes with the multiplication of A, as in r \cdot (ab) = (r \cdot a)b = a(r \cdot b).
A Lie algebra is a vector space \mathfrak{g} together with a binary operation [-, -], its Lie bracket, satisfying:

ul.li: skew-symmetry: [x, y] = -[y, x];
bilinearity: [x+cy, z] = [x, z] + c[y, z];
the Jacobi identity: [x, [y, z]] + [z, [x, y]] + [y, [x, z]] = 0.

mainmatter.p: Here, we give one story of the construction of the real numbers.
An ordered field is a field (F, +, \cdot ) with a total order \leq, compatible

ul.li: additively: y < z implies x + y < x + z;
multiplicatively: 0 < x and 0 < y implies 0 < xy.

frontmatter.title: Ordered fields contain \mathbb{Q} as a subfield

mainmatter.p: Any ordered field contains a subfield isomorphic to \mathbb{Q}.
By elementary properties of ordered fields, any ordered field has characteristic 0, and hence contains a copy of \mathbb{Z}. Closing under multiplicative inverses gives a copy of \mathbb{Q}.

frontmatter.title: Uniqueness of ordered fields with the lub property

mainmatter.p: Any two ordered fields satisfying the least upper bound property are isomorphic as ordered fields.
Let (F, +, \cdot , \leq ) and (G, +, \cdot , \leq ) be ordered fields satisfying the lub property. It suffices to construct an ordered field isomorphism F \xrightarrow{\varphi} G.
Let \mathbb{Q} \xrightarrow{f} F and \mathbb{Q} \xrightarrow{g} G be injective with images the isomorphic copies of \mathbb{Q} in F and G.
TODO.
A module over a ring R, or just an R-module, is an abelian group (M, +) together with an action R \curvearrowright M which preserves the following structure:

ul.li: identities: 1_R \cdot x = x, 0_R \cdot x = 0_M;
distributivity: r \cdot (x+y) = r \cdot x + r \cdot y, (r+s) \cdot x = r \cdot x + s \cdot x;
multipication: r \cdot (s \cdot x) = (rs) \cdot x.

mainmatter.p: A relation R between sets X and Y is a subset of the cartesian product X \times Y. We write xRy when (x, y) \in R.
A relation \sim is reflexive if for any x, x \sim x.
A relation \sim is symmetric if for any x,y, if x \sim y, then y \sim x.
A relation \sim is antisymmetric if for any x,y, if x \sim y, then not y \sim x.
A relation \sim is transitive if for any x,y,z, if x \sim y and y \sim z, then x \sim z.
A preorder is a reflexive and transitive relation.
A partial order is an antisymmetric preorder.
A partial order is total if any two elements are comparable, i.e., either x \leq y or y \leq x for every x and y in the set.
In a partial ordered set (X, \leq ), a set Y \subseteq X is bounded above if there exists an x \in X such that y \leq x for every y \in Y. Such an x is an upper bound of Y.
In a partial ordered set (X, \leq ), the join, supremum, or least upper bound of a set Y \subseteq X, if it exists, is an element \bigvee Y such that:

ul.li: \bigvee Y is an upper bound of Y;
if z \leq \bigvee Y, then z is not an upper bound of Y.

mainmatter.p: A partial order (X, \leq ) has the least upper bound property if every nonempty bounded above subset of X has a least upper bound.
As a special case of categorical duality, every definition in order theory admits a syntactic dual by reversing the order. We generally prefer to work in terms of \leq rather than \geq.
A poset has the least upper bound property if and only if it has the (dually defined) greatest lower bound property.
Let (X, \leq ) have the lub property; we show the glb property, and conclude by duality. Let Y \subseteq X be nonempty and bounded below. Let y \in Y.

Let L be the set of lower bounds of Y; L is nonempty since Y is bounded below. By definition of lower bound, l \leq y for all l \in L. Now L is bounded above by y, and hence has a supremum \bigvee L by the lub property. By definition of the supremum and construction of L, we have that \bigvee L \geq l for any lower bound l of Y; hence \bigvee L = \bigwedge Y, completing the proof.
A vector space over a field F, or just an F-vector space, is a module over F.
A group is abelian if its operation is commutative.
A binary operation \cdot on a set X is associative if for any x,y,z \in X, (x \cdot y) \cdot z = x \cdot (y \cdot z).
A binary operation on a set X is a function X \times X\rightarrow X.
The cartesian product of sets X and Y is the set \{ (x, y): x \in X, y \in Y \} .
A classical monoid is a semigroup with an identity.
A binary operation \cdot on a set X is commutative if for any x,y \in X, x \cdot y = y \cdot x.
A field is a ring which is also an abelian group under multiplication.
A group is a classical monoid (G, \cdot , e) such that each element g \in G has a two-sided inverse g^{-1} \in G, i.e. such that g \cdot g^{-1} = g^{-1} \cdot g = e.
An identity for a [binary operation] \cdot on a set X is an element e \in X such that e \cdot x = x \cdot e = x for all x \in X.
A magma is a set together with a binary operation.
A ring is a set R which is both an abelian group (R, +) and a monoid (R, \times ), such that multiplication distributes over addition, i.e. r \times (s + q) = r \times s + r \times q.
A semigroup is a magma whose operation is associative.
A functor C \xrightarrow{F} D is essentially surjective on objects if for every d \in D, there is a c \in C such that Fc is isomorphic to d.
A functor is faithful if its action on hom-sets is injective.
A functor is full if its action on hom-sets is surjective.

Morphism composition is more naturally expressed in left-to-right application order; this reflects diagrammatic and (for anglophones) linguistic convention. Since convention dictates that fg means g then f, we use f; g to mean f then g.

Due to the desirability of consistent notations, we always prefer 1_x as the notation for an identity on some object or operation x; for example, we prefer 1_G for the identity of a multiplcative groupG, where e is somewhat more conventional.
Even across different fields, it's desirable to maintain as consistent a notational convention as possible, to reduce overhead in context-switching.

tree.mainmatter:
A strict 0-category is a set.
A strict (n+1)-category is a category enriched over nCat, the category of all strict n-categories.For the definition to make sense, it must hold that nCat is monoidal;

mainmatter.p: A bifunctor is a functor out of a product category.
Let (K, \otimes , 1_ \otimes , \alpha , \lambda , \rho ) be a monoidal category. A category enriched over K (also called a K-category), C, consists of:

ul.li: a collection of objects, overloadingly also called C;
for each pair of objects x,y in C, an object C(x, y) of K;
for each object x in C, a designated identity morphism 1_ \otimes \xrightarrow{1_x} C(x, x);
for each triple of objects x,y,z in C, a designated composite morphism C(y,z) \otimes C(x,y) \xrightarrow{\circ _{x,y,z}} C(x,z).

mainmatter.p: This data must satisfy the associative and unit laws:
The hom-bifunctor C(-, -) on a category C takes a pair of objects to their hom-set:
The product of two categories C and D has pairs of objects as objects, pairs of morphisms as morphisms, pairs of identities as identities, and composition component-wise.
Fixing an object c of some category C, the contravariant hom-functor at c, C(-, c), takes a map to its action by pre-composition:
Fixing an object c of some category C, the covariant hom-functor at c, C(c, -), takes a map to its action by post-composition:
A continuous function between topological spaces T and S is a function f such that, for each open set U \in S, its preimage f^{-1}(U) is open in T.
Set is a category whose objects are sets and whose morphisms are set-functions.
Top is a category whose objects are topological spaces and whose morphisms are continuous functions.
A topological space is a tuple (X, O), where O \subseteq \mathcal{P} (X) are called the open sets, such that:

ul.li: \varnothing \in O, X \in O;
O is closed under arbitrary unions;
O is closed under finite intersections.

mainmatter.p: A relation \sim is antisymmetric if for any x,y, if x \sim y, then not y \sim x.
An equivalence relation is a reflexive, symmetric, and transitive relation.
The identity functor C \xrightarrow{1_C} C over a category C acts as the identity on both objects and morphisms.
The identity natural transformation F \xRightarrow{1_F} F over a functor F has the identity morphism 1_{Fx} for each of its components.
A relation \sim is reflexive if for any x, x \sim x.
A relation \sim is symmetric if for any x,y, if x \sim y, then y \sim x.
A relation \sim is transitive if for any x,y,z, if x \sim y and y \sim z, then x \sim z.
In a partial ordered set (X, \leq ), a set Y \subseteq X is bounded above if there exists an x \in X such that y \leq x for every y \in Y. Such an x is an upper bound of Y.
In a partial ordered set (X, \leq ), the join, supremum, or least upper bound of a set Y \subseteq X, if it exists, is an element \bigvee Y such that:

ul.li: \bigvee Y is an upper bound of Y;
if z \leq \bigvee Y, then z is not an upper bound of Y.

mainmatter.p: A partial order (X, \leq ) has the least upper bound property if every nonempty bounded above subset of X has a least upper bound.
As a special case of categorical duality, every definition in order theory admits a syntactic dual by reversing the order. We generally prefer to work in terms of \leq rather than \geq.
A partial order is an antisymmetric preorder.
A relation R between sets X and Y is a subset of the cartesian product X \times Y. We write xRy when (x, y) \in R.

Let F \xRightarrow{\alpha} G and G \xRightarrow{\beta} H be natural transformations with components \alpha _x and \beta _x, respectively. Then their vertical compositeF \xRightarrow{\beta \alpha} H is a natural transformation with components ( \beta \alpha )_x = \beta _x \alpha _x.
An endofunctor over a category C is a functorC \rightarrow C.
The endofunctor category [C, C] over a category C is a strict monoidal category with:

ul.li: horizontal composition as the tensor product;
the identity functor as the tensor unit.

mainmatter.p: Fix categories C and D. The functor category [C, D] consists of:

ul.li: functors C \rightarrow D as objects;
natural transformations as morphisms;
vertical composition as composition;
the identity natural transformations as identities.

mainmatter.p: Let C \xrightarrow{F,F'} D and D \xrightarrow{G,G'} E be functors with F \xRightarrow{\alpha} F' and G \xRightarrow{\beta} G' natural transformations. Then their horizontal composite GF \xRightarrow{\beta * \alpha} G'F' is a natural transformation with components given by the following commutative square:
A monad over a category C is a monoid object in the endofunctor category over C.
A strict monoidal category is a monoidal category for which the associators and unitors are each the identity natural transformation.
A monoid object in a monoidal category (K, \otimes , 1_ \otimes , \alpha , \lambda , \rho ) consists of the following data:

ul.li: an object m \in K;
a multiplication m \otimes m \xrightarrow{\mu} m;
a unit 1_ \otimes \xrightarrow{\eta} m.

mainmatter.p: This data must be associative and unital, in the sense of the following diagrams:
A monoidal structure on a category K consists of the following data:

ul.li: a bifunctor \otimes : K \times K \rightarrow K called the tensor product;
an object 1_ \otimes \in K called the tensor unit;

mainmatter.p: This data must satisfy the triangle and pentagon identities:
A natural isomorphism is a natural transformation whose components are each isomorphisms.
Category theory admits a kind of syntactic duality via the opposite category, through which any theorem immediately obtains a dual via "reversing all the arrows" in the theorem and proof.
A contravariant functor F between categories C and D is a functor out of the opposite category:
A functor F: C \rightarrow D between categories C and D consists of the following data:

ul.li: for each object c \in C, an object Fc \in D;
for each morphism x \xrightarrow{f} y in C, a morphism Fx \xrightarrow{Ff} Fy in D.

mainmatter.p: This data must preserve the categorical structure, that is:

ul.li: for each x \xrightarrow{f} y \xrightarrow{g} z in C, (Fg) (Ff) = F(gf);
for each c \in C, F1_c = 1_{Fc}.

mainmatter.p: A groupoid is a category whose morphisms are each isomorphisms.

A natural transformation F \xRightarrow{\alpha} G between functors C \xrightarrow{F,G} D consists of, for each object c \in C, a morphism Fc \xrightarrow{\alpha _c} Gc \in D, called the components of \alpha.
This data must preserve morphisms in C, in the sense that for any morphism x \xrightarrow{f} y \in C, the square
must commute.
Fix a category C. The opposite category C^{ \text{op} } consists of:

ul.li: the same objects as in C;
for each morphism x \xrightarrow{f} y in C, a morphism y \xrightarrow{f^{ \text{op} }} x.

mainmatter.p: Composition is given contrapositively, as in the equality
Suppose x \xrightarrow{s} y \xrightarrow{r} x = 1_x. Then s is a section or pre-inverse and r is a retract or post-inverse.
A category C consists of the following data:

ul.li: a collection of objects, overloadingly also called C;
for each pair of objects x,y \in C, a collection of morphisms #C(x, y);
for each object x \in C, a designated identity morphism x \xrightarrow{1_x} x;
for each pair of morphisms x \xrightarrow{f} y \xrightarrow{g} z, a designated composite morphism x \xrightarrow{gf} z.

mainmatter.p: This data must satisfy the following axioms:

ul.li: unitality: for any x \xrightarrow{f} y, 1_yf = f = f1_x;
associativity: for any x \xrightarrow{f} y \xrightarrow{g} z \xrightarrow{h} w, (hg)f = h(gf).

mainmatter.p: In other words, the following diagrams must commute:
A morphism x \xrightarrow{f} y in a category C is an epimorphism if for any parallel morphisms y \xrightarrow{h,k} z, hf = kf implies h = k.
A morphism x \xrightarrow{f} y in a category C is an isomorphism if there exists an inverse morphism y \xrightarrow{g} x such that fg = 1_y and gf = 1_x.
A morphism x \xrightarrow{f} y in a category C is a monomorphism if for any parallel morphisms z \xrightarrow{h,k} x, fh = fk implies h = k.
I am an undergraduate Math-CS major at Reed College. My pronouns are she/they.
This site hosts my public Zettlekasten-style notes. To search these, try Ctrl-K, or check out the list of lists. It relies on the fantastic Forester, by Jon Sterling.

Girard's phase semantics, which may be instantiated with any (classical) monoid, are a canonical model of this logic. We give a categorical generalization of phase semantics to monoid objects in certain categories, filling an existing hole in the categorical semantics of linear logic. Along the way, we introduce and motivate the project of categorical semantics, assuming no knowledge of category theory or logic. This talk presents research with Steve Zdancewic at the UPenn PLClub group, supported by the REPL NSF REU site.

frontmatter.title: Categorical phase semantics for linear logic

mainmatter.p: Linear logic is a logic of limited resources, useful in practice for writing safe programs. Girard's phase semantics, which may be instantiated with any (classical) monoid, are a canonical model of this logic. We give a categorical generalization of phase semantics to monoid objects in certain categories, filling an existing hole in the categorical semantics of linear logic. Along the way, we introduce and motivate the project of categorical semantics, assuming no knowledge of category theory or logic.
